title: Alex Tulou
text:
Alex Tulou (born March 21, 1987 in <a href="Faga%27alu">Faga'alu</a>, <a href="American%20Samoa">American Samoa</a>) is a <a href="rugby%20union">rugby union</a> footballer, currently playing in the top French professional rugby competition, the <a href="Top%2014">Top 14</a>, for <a href="Montpellier%20H%C3%A9rault%20RC">Montpellier</a>. He joined Montpellier in 2011. His usual position is <a href="Rugby%20union%20positions%238.%20Number%20Eight">number eight</a> or <a href="Flanker%20%28rugby%20union%29">Flanker</a>.
Career.
Alex started his school boy rugby at Hastings Boys' High School in the province of Hawkes Bay, New Zealand. He was quickly identified as an up-and-coming young player with tremendous strength, ball skills and speed.
Tulou started his career with the <a href="Taranaki%20Rugby%20Football%20Union">Taranaki</a> in the <a href="National%20Provincial%20Championship%20%282006%E2%80%93present%29">National Provincial Championship</a> and the <a href="Hurricanes%20%28rugby%20union%29">Hurricanes</a> in the <a href="Super%20Rugby">Super 14</a>. During this time he had a trial for the <a href="All%20Blacks%20Sevens%20team">New Zealand 7's team</a>.
In 2010 he signed a two-year contract to play for <a href="CS%20Bourgoin-Jallieu">Bourgoin</a> in the <a href="Top%2014">Top 14</a>. He played 15 Top 14 matches (9 starts and 6 as a replacement) for the club in the 2010/11 season, scoring 3 tries, and 4 matches in the <a href="European%20Challenge%20Cup">European Challenge Cup</a>, scoring one try.
Following this he signed for <a href="Montpellier%20H%C3%A9rault%20RC">Montpellier</a> to replace <a href="J%C3%A9r%C3%B4me%20Vall%C3%A9e">Jérôme Vallée</a> after he was forced to retire due to injury. He played a further 8 matches for Montpellier in 2010/11 but failed to add to his try tally.
During the 2011/12 season, Tulou established himself as a first team regular for Montpellier, starting 19 of the team's 27 league games at Number 8 and was a replacement for 5 more. He scored 9 tries, including the team's first try in their end of season playoff defeat to Castres. Tulou also played in his first <a href="Heineken%20Cup">Heineken Cup</a> matches, scoring one try.
In September 2012 it was announced that Tulou had signed a new contract to keep him at <a href="Montpellier%20H%C3%A9rault%20RC">Montpellier</a> until 2015.
Afterwards he signed for French rivals <a href="Castres%20Olympique">Castres</a> from the 2015-16 season. Afterwards, he rejected a move to <a href="Pro%20D2">Pro D2</a> side <a href="AS%20Beziers%20Herault">Beziers</a>, he instead signed for another French club <a href="Lyon%20OU">Lyon</a> to remain in the <a href="Top%2014">Top 14</a> from the 2020-21 season.
